comment.author: 29056926@N02
comment._content: This slide's title syas "Statue of Horse", but I see this statue referred to as "Cart-Horse Group" in other locations and not as "Statue of Horse". Are both correct? Here are a few references. Another glass lantern slide at the School of the Art Institute of Chicago. (was that lantern moved/replaced, or is there a crazy lens effect??) Caption in 1894 pressing of "Art and Handicraft of the Woman's Building"

comment.author: 83979593@N00
comment._content: Wow, Roketpad your eye totally impresses us!  It looks like a different placement too...

comment.author: 29056926@N02
comment._content:
You know what?  I've been flipping back and forth between this photo and the Art Institute of Chicago photo I linked to above.

Now I don't think there was any change in the electric light!

An optical illusion makes it look like the light in this photo is in front of the statue.  Really, it's far behind it, and almost exactly lined up with a pole in the fenced railing.

I couldn't figure out why they'd have different light poles around the Court of Honor.

comment.author: 29056926@N02
comment._content: By Daniel Chester French (he did the Statue of the Republic as well) and Edward Clark Potter. Per Art & Architecture of the Women's Building, 1894 edition page 123.
